conclusion: Determine the time it takes for light to travel through the isosceles prism ABC.
The prism is isosceles with vertex angle θ = 30°.
The light enters at the midpoint O of side AB.
Since the light exits perpendicular to side AC, it travels straight through the prism without deviation upon exiting.
Use Snell's Law at the point of incidence O: n sin(i) = sin(r), where n is the refractive index of the prism.
The angle of refraction at the exit is 0°, implying the light travels parallel to the base BC inside the prism.
The angle r inside the prism is equal to the angle of the prism at O, which is θ/2 = 15°.
Using Snell's Law: n sin(45°) = sin(15°), n √2/2 = sin(15°), n = sin(15°)/(√2/2).
The light travels from O to the point where it exits perpendicular to AC.
Since O is the midpoint of AB, the length of AO is L/2.
The path length inside the prism is L/2 sec(15°).
The speed of light in the prism is C/n.
The time t taken for light to travel through the prism is t = (Path Length)/(Speed in Prism) = (L/2 sec(15°))/(C/n).
Substitute the value of n: n = sin(15°)/(√2/2).
The time of propagation is t = (L/2C) (sin(15°)/(√2/2)) sec(15°).
